docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 19th century, the United States was both a rapidly industrializing nation and -- as Charles Dickens, among others, knew all too well -- a bold pirate of intellectual property. But these days, when it comes to dealing with developing nations around the world, the United States seems to be ignoring its own swashbuckling heritage. Or at least that's the implication of a recent report by the international Commission on Intellectual Property Rights. The report recommends that the World Trade Organization's treaty on intellectual property rights be made much more flexible so that developing nations, from Brazil to Bangladesh, can adopt rules more at their own pace.

headline.main: New Economy; The intellectual property debate takes a page from 19th-century America.

docs.abstract: Steve Lohr New Economy column notes radical change in American attitude toward intellectual property rights: 19th-century United States contravened them, but 21st-century US demands their enforcement; developed nations, as holders of intellectual property, benefit from fees and royalties that developing world pays to use protected copyrights, patents and trademarks; debate continues over formulating future treaties concerning intellectual property; drawing; graph (M)
docs.snippet: IN the 19th century, the United States was both a rapidly industrializing nation and -- as Charles Dickens, among others, knew all too well -- a bold pirate of intellectual property.     But these days, when it comes to dealing with developing...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who inherit common variants of two genes have 10 times the risk of developing congestive heart failure, a condition that afflicts five million Americans, researchers say. Congestive heart failure is a leading cause of death in the nation, but the researchers say their findings may help doctors identify drugs that are most likely to help patients and to find people at high risk early enough to arrest the disease.

headline.main: 2 Altered Genes Are Linked To Congestive Heart Failure

docs.abstract: University of Cincinnati researchers report people who inherit common variants of two genes have 10 times risk of developing congestive heart failure, condition that afflicts five million Americans; experiments involving 159 patients with congestive heart failure discussed; found one of altered genes confers fivefold increase in risk of heart failure, while other has no effect by itself but leads to tenfold increase when combined with alterations in first gene; suggest patients with gene alterations might be helped by drugs that can impede altered genes' effects; show how altered genes can amplify each other to cause disease; experts laud results as among first soundings of new era in medicine in which doctors identify individual's genetic variations to help them avoid illness (M)
docs.snippet: People who inherit common variants of two genes have 10 times the risk of developing congestive heart failure, a condition that afflicts five million Americans, researchers say.     Congestive heart failure is a leading cause of death in the nation,...

docs.lead_paragraph: These are soul-searching days in this Westchester County village, where teenage drinking has long been a fixture, as in other affluent suburbs. Last month's homecoming bacchanal here, which left scores of students falling-down drunk, 27 with three-day school suspensions and five hospitalized with acute alcohol poisoning, has Scarsdale shamefaced and reeling. ''There are an awful lot of parents who all of a sudden have to be looking inside themselves,'' said Scarsdale's mayor, David Kroenlein.

headline.main: Teenagers' Binge Leads Scarsdale to Painful Self-Reflection

docs.abstract: Scarsdale, NY, residents engage in painful soul-searching and introspection over Sept 20 homecoming bacchanal that left scores of high school students falling-down drunk, 27 with three-day school suspensions and five hospitalized with acute alcohol poisoning; affluent village is shame-faced and reeling; soul-searching reaches climax when about 300 mothers and fathers gather in school auditorium for communitywide meeting; photo (M)
